courses.subject: ECLT
courses.title: Fundamentals of E-Commerce Technologies
courses.description: An overview of the principles of E-Commerce. The origin and growth of E-Commerce. Technologies that support the development of E-Commerce applications. Business models and strategies for E-Commerce. Legal issues related to E-Commerce such as privacy, consumer rights and intellectual property. Information interchange and application sharing via extensible markup languages and web services to support logistics and operations management.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MSc E-Commerce & Logistics Technologies
courses.academic_group: Div of System Erg & Erg Mgt
courses.academic_org: Div of System Erg & Erg Mgt
courses.learning_outcomes: After completing the course, a student should have understandings of the fundamentals and background information about E-Commerce Technologies.
courses.course_syllabus:
E-Commerce Introduction
E-Commerce Infrastructure
E-Commerce Security & Payment Systems
E-Commerce Business Strategies
E-commerce Marketing and Advertising
Online Media
Online Communities
E-Commerce Retail
B2B E-Commerce
courses.recommended_readings:
Kenneth C. Laudon & Carol Guercio Traver, E-commerce 2015: business, technology, society, 11th Edition, Global Edition, Pearson, 2015 (LT)

David D. VanHoose, E-Commerce Economics, 2nd edition, Routledge, 2011 (DV) (e-book available through the library’s webpage).

courses.subject: ECLT
courses.title: Electronic Payments Systems
courses.description: This course covers various methods of transferring payments over the Internet andcompares their functionality. Topics include electronic money, electronic contracts, micro-payments, authenticity, integrity and reliability of transactions, encryption and digital signature techniques needed to support electronic cash, and technologies available to support secure transactions on the Internet.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MSc E-Commerce & Logistics Technologies
courses.academic_group: Div of System Erg & Erg Mgt
courses.academic_org: Div of System Erg & Erg Mgt
courses.learning_outcomes: After completing the course, a student should understand the characteristics of payment systems; the motivation of electronic payment; major electronic payment business models; electronic payment system infrastructure and related security issues; major electronic payment systems; various cryptographic techniques that are used by electronic payment systems; and relevant legal issues.
courses.course_syllabus:
Electronic payments systems overview
Information security overview
Security protocol analysis
Credit card based systems
Digital Money
Micropayment
Mobile payment
courses.required_readings: M. H. Sharif, Protocols for Secure Electronic Commerce, 2nd Edition, CRC
courses.recommended_readings:
Weidong Kou, Payment Technologies for E-Commerce, 1st Edition, Springer.

Donal O’Mahony, Michael Peirce, Hitesh Tewari, Electronic Payment Systems for E-Commerce, 2nd Edition, Artech House.

courses.subject: ECLT
courses.title: Logistics Management
courses.description:
After completing the course, a student should have developed an appreciation of the practical significance and complexities of logistics management,
gained an understanding of the key processes involved, and mastered some analytical tools useful in the designing, operating and improving of a
logistics system.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MSc E-Commerce & Logistics Technologies
courses.academic_group: Div of System Erg & Erg Mgt
courses.academic_org: Div of System Erg & Erg Mgt
courses.learning_outcomes: After completing the course, a student should have developed an appreciation of the practical significance and complexities of logistics management, gained an understanding of the key processes involved, and mastered some analytical tools useful in the designing, operating and improving of a logistics system.
courses.course_syllabus: According to the course teacher in the respective teaching term.
courses.required_readings: Ghiani, G., G. Laporte and R. Musmanno, Introduction to Logistics Systems Management, 2013, Wiley.
courses.recommended_readings:
Ballou, R.H., Business Logistics Management/Supply Chain Management, 5th edition, 2004, Prentice-Hall.

Christopher, M., Logistics and Supply Chain Management (4th edition), 2011, Financial Times/ Prentice-Hall.

courses.subject: ECLT
courses.title: E-Commerce Data Mining Techniques
courses.description:
After completing the course, a student should understand the foundation in data mining concepts and techniques, and acquire the knowledge of Ecommerce
data mining applications.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MSc E-Commerce & Logistics Technologies
courses.academic_group: Div of System Erg & Erg Mgt
courses.academic_org: Div of System Erg & Erg Mgt
courses.learning_outcomes: After completing the course, a student should understand the foundation in data mining concepts and techniques, and acquire the knowledge of E-commerce data mining applications.
courses.course_syllabus:
Data Pre-processing
Classification; Decision Tree Induction
Decision Tree Induction
Model Evaluation; Practical Consideration
Enterprise Miner: Introduction and Complete Example
Logistic Regression
Case Study in Loan Application
Enterprise Miner: Decision Tree, Regression; SAS programming
Clustering
Association Rule Discovery
Neural Networks
Weka Data Mining Package
courses.required_readings:
“Data Mining - Concepts and Techniques”, J. Han, M. Kamber, and J. Pei (Morgan
Kaufmann)

“Data Science for Business”, F. Provost and T. Fawcett, O’Reilly

courses.subject: ECLT
courses.title: Distributed and Mobile Systems
courses.description: Distributed and mobile systems are the key framework for E-Commerce applications. This course covers the principles of distributed systems (including mobile applications) and software, and the engineering mechanisms for their specifi cation, design, deployment, and evaluation. Topics include: architectural models for distributed systems, server techniques, remote procedure call and multicast communications, RFID technology, emerging standards and platforms, distributed transactions, concurrency control, reliability and security issues.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MSc E-Commerce & Logistics Technologies
courses.academic_group: Div of System Erg & Erg Mgt
courses.academic_org: Div of System Erg & Erg Mgt
courses.learning_outcomes: After completing the course, a student should have learned the problems that occur during construction of distributed systems; the principles and techniques to solve them; the infrastructure and components for distributed and mobile systems; and the practical applications of distributed systems, particularly in e-commerce technologies.
courses.course_syllabus:
Characterization of Distributed Systems
Communication and RPC
Security
Naming, Trading, and P2P Systems
Time, Coordination and Agreement
Concurrency Control
Transactions
Fault Tolerance and Replication
Mobile, Ubiquitous Computing
Blockchain, Bitcoin, and Ethereum
Cloud Computing
courses.required_readings: Distributed Systems: Concepts and Design, George Coulouris, Jean Dollimore, and Tim Kindberg, Addison-Wesley, 5th edition, 2012.

courses.subject: ECLT
courses.title: Network and Web Programming
courses.description: This course addresses the techniques for programming in both low-level (Network) and high-level (Web) of internet. Network programs includes: Client-server system design; sockets; etc. Web programming includes: HTML, CSS, JavaScript, Web page design and construction. The course also explores on modern topics including serverless systems and web security issues.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MSc E-Commerce & Logistics Technologies
courses.academic_group: Div of System Erg & Erg Mgt
courses.academic_org: Div of System Erg & Erg Mgt
courses.learning_outcomes: After completing the course, a student should understand and develop distributed applications using selected network and web programming technologies.
courses.course_syllabus:
Front-End Web Development
• HTML
• CSS
• JavaScript
• DOM manipulation and event handling
• Front-End Framework
Back-End Web Development
• Server-Side Scripting
• Database Management System
Network Communication
• HTTP
• Blocking and non-blocking communication
• Web Communication APIs (XMLHttpRequest, Websockets, Server Sent Events, etc.)
Web Security and OAuth 2
Others
• Web Session
• JSON
• Web Services
• Asynchronous Programming in JavaScript
courses.recommended_readings:
- Northwood, Chris. The Full Stack Developer: Your Essential Guide to the Everyday Skills Expected of a Modern Full Stack Web Developer (2018).

- Ferguson, Russ. Beginning JavaScript: The Ultimate Guide to Modern JavaScript Development (2019).

Luke Welling and Laura Thomson, PHP and MySQL web development, Addison-Wesley, 2009

courses.subject: ECLT
courses.title: Open Systems for E-Commerce

meetings.location: William M W Mong Eng Bldg LT

courses.description: Introduction to open system standards and protocols. Transaction protocols. Electronic commerce applications using open system and artificial intelligence technologies. Application of intelligent agents for automated transaction processing. Integration of web programming techniques with information and communication systems. Case studies for E-Commerce open system applications.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MSc E-Commerce & Logistics Technologies
courses.academic_group: Div of System Erg & Erg Mgt
courses.academic_org: Div of System Erg & Erg Mgt
courses.learning_outcomes: After completing the course, a student should have knowledge about the backbone technologies of E-Commerce.
courses.course_syllabus:
Data Mobility: Open Systems
Database Systems: Talk to Data
Bitcoin and Blockchain
courses.required_readings:
Computer Networking: A Top-Down Approach Featuring the Internet (5th edition) by James F. Kurose and Keith W. Ross, Addison Wesley, 2009.

Introduction to Data Mining, by Pang-Ning Tan, Michael Steinbach, and Vipin Kumar, Addison Wesley, 2005.

courses.subject: ECLT
courses.title: Project I in E-Commerce and Logistics Technologies

meetings.instructor:
Dr. PAN Hong, 
Professor GAO Xuefeng

Dr. PAN Hong, 
Professor GAO Xuefeng

courses.description: An individual or a team project on E-Commerce technologies.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MSc E-Commerce & Logistics Technologies
courses.academic_group: Div of System Erg & Erg Mgt
courses.academic_org: Div of System Erg & Erg Mgt
courses.learning_outcomes:
After completing a project, a student might have involved in the following (not restricted):
Design of a system related to E-commerce, development, test and evaluation; Development and/or application of a theory or model to understand or analyze a system or a process; Case study of a real application or process; and/or Simulation of a system or process based on an analytical or computational model.
courses.course_syllabus:
Case Study of Inventory Model
Big Data in E-Commerce: Techniques and Application
Financial Index Tracking
Network Optimization Problem with Application
courses.required_readings:
Robert T. Clemen, Making Hard Decisions: An Introduction to Decision Analysis, Duxbury Press, 1996.

A, Shtub, J.F. Bard, and S. Globerson, Project Management: Engineering, Technology, and Implementation, Prentice Hall, 1994.

courses.subject: ECLT
courses.title: Information Technology Management
courses.description: The challenges, techniques and technologies associated with the management of information technology (IT) for logistics and supply chain operations. The linkage of IT to business models and corporate strategies in logistics and supply chain industry. Information systems and technology planning, sourcing and acquisition, budgeting and deployment. Performance evaluation and audit. Standard, privacy and security policies.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MSc E-Commerce & Logistics Technologies
courses.academic_group: Div of System Erg & Erg Mgt
courses.academic_org: Div of System Erg & Erg Mgt
courses.learning_outcomes: After completing the course, a student should understand the important facets of managing information technology which emphasizes the strategic perspectives of information system management and the importance of matching business models with the new technologies in E-commerce.
courses.course_syllabus:
Introduction and Digital Economy, Grown Up Digitals
Long-term Planning: IT Strategic Planning
Long-term Planning: SWOT, PEST, Porter’s 5-Force Model
Mid-term Planning: Entrepreneurship & Lean Launch Pad
Mid-term Planning: Business Plan
Short-term Planning: System Development Life Cycle (SDLC)
Short-term Planning: Project Planning, Design Strategy
courses.required_readings: Efraim Turban, Linda Volonio, “Information Technology for Management: Transforming Organizations in the Digital Economy”, 7th Edition, Wiley.

courses.subject: ECLT
courses.title: Decision Methodologies with Financial Applications

meetings.location: William M W Mong Eng Bldg LT

courses.description: Cash flow analysis, portfolio optimization, capital asset pricing theory, derivative contracts, no-arbitrage pricing theory, risk management.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MSc E-Commerce & Logistics Technologies
courses.academic_group: Div of System Erg & Erg Mgt
courses.academic_org: Div of System Erg & Erg Mgt
courses.learning_outcomes: After completing the course, students are expected to understand basic decision methodologies and their applications in finance.
courses.course_syllabus:
Cash flow analysis
Mean-Variance Analysis
Capital Asset Pricing Model
Options, forward, and futures
Binomial tree model
Brownian motion and Ito Lemma
Black-Scholes Model
American options
Risk management
Interest rate term structure
courses.required_readings:
D. G. Luenberger, Investment Science, 2nd edition, Oxford University Press, 2013

J.C. Hull, Options, Futures, and Other Derivatives, latest ed., Prentice Hall

courses.subject: ECLT
courses.title: Engineering Economics
courses.description: Principles of engineering economy. Value and cost, cash flows. Economic analysis of alternatives, technological, social and human factors. Models involving allocation and scheduling of resources. Analytical techniques for evaluating industrial projects. Relationship between economics of technical choice and industrial productivity. Basic financial accounting concepts, financial statements.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MSc E-Commerce & Logistics Technologies
courses.academic_group: Div of System Erg & Erg Mgt
courses.academic_org: Div of System Erg & Erg Mgt
courses.learning_outcomes: At the conclusion of this course, students were able to understand basic cost concepts, terminology, and methods to estimate and optimize cost of design projects; understand time value of money and apply this knowledge through various methods to evaluate alternative projects; and learn the techniques to account for depreciation, tax, and inflation in the evaluation of engineering projects.
courses.course_syllabus:
Introduction to Engineering Economy
Cost Concepts and Design Economics
Cost-Estimation Techniques
The Time Value of Money
Evaluating a Single Project
Comparison and Selection among Alternatives
Depreciation and Income Taxes
Price Changes and Exchange Rates
Evaluating Projects with the Benefit-Cost Ratio Method
Dealing with Uncertainty
courses.required_readings: Engineering Economy, William G. Sullivan; Elin M. Wicks; C. Patrick Koelling

courses.subject: ECLT
courses.title: Supply Chain Management
courses.description: Management of moving raw materials, in-process inventory and finished-goods; transferring information and payment. Topics include: electronic information and payment transfer and its impact, distribution, forecasting, inventory management, purchasing and supplier management, ERP systems supply chain integration and strategic partnering. Impacts of E-Commerce in supply chain management.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MSc E-Commerce & Logistics Technologies
courses.academic_group: Div of System Erg & Erg Mgt
courses.academic_org: Div of System Erg & Erg Mgt
courses.learning_outcomes: After completing the course, a student should have learned the SCM vocabulary; understood major qualitative features regarding the operations of a supply chain and learned some basic SCM analytical tools and gained insights into the IT implications.
courses.course_syllabus:
Introduction to Supply Chain Management
Network Design
Demand Forecasting
Aggregate Planning and S&OP
Inventory Management – Cycle Inventory
Inventory Management – Safety Inventory
Inventory Management – Product Availability
Vehicle Routing
Sustainable Supply Chains
courses.required_readings: Chopra and Meindl, Supply Chain Management: Strategy, Planning and Operation, 5th edition, 2013, Pearson
courses.recommended_readings:
Heizer and Render, Operations Management: Sustainability and Supply Chain Management, 11th edition, 2014, Pearson

Nahmias, Production and Operations Analysis, 6th Edition, 2008, Irwin/McGraw-Hill

courses.subject: ECLT
courses.title: E-Commerce and Logistics Technologies Internship

meetings.instructor:
Dr. PAN Hong, 
Professor GAO Xuefeng

courses.description:
The objective of the course is to allow students to acquire a basic understanding and the skills of the practical aspects of E-Commerce and Logistics Technologies. To qualify for the award of the subject credits, the student must attach to a company in an E-Commerce and Logistics Technologies related post as approved by the Professor-in-Charge for no less than 12 weeks. The student will have an academic supervisor as assigned by the Professor-in-Charge and an industry supervisor from the company. There will be a mid-term company visit by the academic supervisor. At the end of the internship, the student must give a presentation to the academic and industry supervisors, and submit a report summarizing what the student has done and learnt from the internship. The student's grade will be determined by (1) the presentation, (2) the student report and (3) a testimonial from the industry supervisor.

The internship should normally take place in the summer term after a student has finished the first two semesters of studies. Part-time students can decide to undertake the internship in the summer term of either the first or second year of studies.

Students are recommended to seek the Professor-in-Charge's comment on potential internship opportunities before enrolling in the course.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MSc E-Commerce & Logistics Technologies
courses.academic_group: Div of System Erg & Erg Mgt
courses.academic_org: Div of System Erg & Erg Mgt
courses.course_syllabus: The objective of the course is to allow students to acquire a basic understanding and the skills of the practical aspects of the E-Commerce and Logistics Technologies. To qualify for the award of the subject credits, the student must attach to a company in an E-Commerce and Logistics Technologies related post as approved by the Professor-in-Charge for no less than 12 weeks. The student will have an academic supervisor as assigned by the Professor-in-Charge and an industry supervisor from the company. There will be a mid-term company visit by the academic supervisor. At the end of the internship, the student must give a presentation to the academic and industry supervisors, and submit a report summarizing what the student has done and learnt from the internship. The student's grade will be determined by (1) the presentation, (2) the student report and (3) a testimonial from the industry supervisor.
